It is not that i didn't understand the deep meaning philosophy there but it is just that i couldn't find any logic in that. A film with 8.1 IMDb rating should be better, this is so Overrated.. at least for me.Rating- 6/10*

The reason I saw The Red Shoes was because I am a tremendous admirer of Martin Scorsese. His work, his outlook, his style, everything about the guy. One of the influences of his that he mentions the most is Michael Powell's work, especially The Red Shoes. I was surprised that I wasn't quite as moved as him. I've never been a fan of musicals, but there are always anomalies. However, I just felt indifferent towards it. One of the things about The Red Shoes that impressed me the most though was Anton Walbrook's performance as the dark, cocksure, self-sufficient producer Boris Lermontov, especially during his spiral into obsession and jealousy. Sharing the charm is beautiful Moira Shearer, whose dancing and increasingly dramatic time on screen become very interesting.As for Michael Powell, he certainly has fashioned himself a majestic, lavish, elegant production in prototype Technicolor. I find that as well as most of Powell's earlier movies, he collaborates with Emeric Pressburger. Perhaps he does the musical numbers and choreography and Powell directs the rest of the movie. Whichever way it goes, the turning- point musical number with the red shoes is easily the best scene in the whole film. It's a fantasy-themed, very extensive musical number that expands further than the stage that the characters are performing upon and is brought into a realm similar to dream sequence or hallucination, but in the lushest possible way.What I find creative is the movie's interpretation of Hans Christian Anderson's story, "The Red Shoes," but what I also find creative about it is also what I find perhaps a bit hindering about it. It doesn't spend enough time on the themes of fantasy, magic, and dance. It spends more time on the process of producing an expensive, elegant theatrical production. Anyway, what it is is a musical that is different and more interesting story-wise than a lot of other more famous musicals of its time, and that's part of its charm.

The dance scenes are outstanding on every level - direction, production, choreography, talent - I just wish there were more of them. It's to the film's detriment that the framing story that occupies the bulk of its runtime is interminable and wastes Moira Shearer. Simply a filmed version of the ballet would have been far superior, without the dramatically inert framing story tacked on.

If anything epitomises the self-praising luvvies of the British film/stage industries, then this is it. It is loved by the critics as a masterpiece of direction and performance. They slap each other on the back, and totally ignore some really bad howlers (called "boners" in the USA).For a start, how many pronunciations are there of "Lermontov?" I counted three. We have a old friend of Boris Lermontov calling him not Borya but Boris, and he stresses the first syllable. Some Russian is he! If these actors, were struggling with their Russian they need only have asked the Moscow-born Leonide Massine. This is just plain sloppy. Instead of being slapped on the back, these so-called actors should have been punched on the nose! In fact, Leonide Massine turns out the only decent acting performance. He is superb throughout.As to Moira Shearer. The Scottish ballerina is a superb dancer but a poor actress. She is supposed to be in emotional turmoil over whether to choose love or career. Instead, she might just as well be choosing whether to have porridge or rice crispies for breakfast.And all the marvellous trick photography of the dance sequences is totally undone by a glaring blunder like high fidelity reception of the BBC Third Programme in Monaco.If the British luvvies spent as much time perfecting their work as they do telling each other how marvellous they are, they might avoid ruining promising films like this.

Moira Shearer is just excellent in this fine example of the cinematographer and choreographer's arts - all under the able and inspired direction of Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger. She is the aspiring ballet dancer "Victoria" who must train under the positively brutal rule of acclaimed tutor "Lermontov" (Anton Walbrook). This maestro, however, expects undiluted devotion and so when this young woman also falls in love - with composer "Craster" (Marius Goring) she finds herself out of favour. Facing the toughest of choices, she chooses love - but even married, she is still torn. When she returns a few years later to visit - her new husband having now completed the eponymous ballet - the imposing "Lermontov" proves he can still pull her strings and she faces an heart-rending choice. P&P have created a masterpiece of rich and colourful cinema. They have turned a relatively simple Hans Christian Anderson story into a maelstrom of love, ambition, power, control - you name it, it features here somewhere. Emotions run high, cruelty runs rife and all under the baton of Brian Easdale who has created his own "Ballet of the Red Shoes" score. Both Walbrook and Goring were underestimated actors, in my view. They had an adaptability that demonstrated a surety of foot as their characters illustrate traits that at best celebrate humanity, at worst denigrate it badly. The dancing is frequently mesmerising with the media of theatre and cinema merged seamlessly to give us a really breathtaking experience. I felt vested in the fate of this young woman, I felt vested in the nasty Lermontov - which would I have chosen? This is a great film, marrying the vivid imagination of a timeless creative source with a visionary and highly entertaining ensemble adaptation. Recently staged by the Sadler's Wells Company of Sir Matthew Bourne, but good as that was - this still knocked spots off it.

Oftentimes as people recommend me movies and I'm led to classic after classic, I really wonder how much I should take the time to watch movies on topics I'm not interested in. Usually, though, I find the recommendations surprisingly good, especially in the case of older movies, because even just the directing and cinematography impress me enough to enjoy my time spent with it.The Red Shoes was another film I was hesitant to watch because I'm simply not terribly interested in the driving forces behind ballet. I find ballet to be pretty and I'm really impressed by the physicality of the dancers, but I couldn't care less about what's going on behind the curtain. But this time, instead of being just impressed with the overall craft of the film, I was blown completely away.Basically, I'd like to remove the first and second half of the film for an instant and comment upon the short film that exists literally in the very center of this film. The Archers, I've heard, grade their films by how close the arrow comes to the bullseye during their insignia at the beginning of the film, and whether that's true or just lore, I think they've nailed the exact center of their goal at the exact center of the film. It's during this part where the in-film production of "The Red Shoes" suddenly floats off the stage and becomes this streaming myriad of color, shape, form, light, shadows, and dance beyond anything I've ever seen created in a visual musical place before and sense. It's very easy to see why this film so impresses filmmakers, artists, and dancers that it is pretty difficult to concentrate on any of those aesthetics without hearing its name. It's also easy to see now why An American in Paris exists, and also why it fails.The performance, with all of its different aspects, was so powerful and effective that I had to watch it again after the film ended, and ended up watching it several times. It's one of those moments in cinema where one wonders, "And there isn't more stuff like this out there WHY?!" but knows immediately that the reason why is that it could have been done only once, only from creators like Emmerich and Pressburger, during only that moment in time when it was produced. It's a meteor shower among the stars, but it's lucky enough to stick around long enough in a close-to-permanent form to be accessed.And I believe that's enough flowery majestic language for it, because the key thing that makes the entire movie work so well is how much it works beyond language. Go and see it.--PolarisDiB

I have seen this movie numerous times and time and time again - it's gets better. As a former dancer I can relate to a lot in this film. You are always struggling with dancing or having a personal life. It's kind of impossible to do both. Think about - can you name 5 famous male ballet dancers? You can't.This movie is visually stunning and the music and costumes are exceptional. If you are a dancer - you will understand and relate to movie like no other - if you are not a dancer - you will relate to this movie like a dancer and a person who has ever been in love or is in love now. It will tug at your heart strings and make you cry - if you let it.Enjoy it with a loved one - trust me - he or she will thank you when the credits start to roll.The first time I saw this movie years ago when I was still dancing - I watched it with my mother (also a former ballerina) and we both cried our eyes out and related to it. Enjoy 10 * out 10.

Yes, the plot of The Red Shoes (1948) is rather hackneyed: a ballerina must choose between her career and romantic love. There's no way her husband will just swallow his pride and let her perform for a man he hates, and there's no way she can find fulfillment dancing for anyone else. In lesser hands, this would be a forgettable weeper, but paired with fine acting, direction, music, and color cinematography, it becomes a haunting fairy tale about art and death.Moira Shearer is heartbreaking as the ballerina torn between two incompatible lifestyles. She also possesses an atypical beauty that you never see much during the classic film era or even today. Anton Walbrook plays a rather unlikeable character, but by the end, you feel sorry for the guy and can even understand where he's coming from. Marius Goring's composer is both infuriating and pathetic.A gorgeous classic. I honestly feel it should have won Best Picture rather than Hamlet (1948). As wonderful as the cinematography in that is, I think this film holds up better overall.

reviews.review_title: Simply THE greatest film on dance ever, and one of the best films full stop
reviews.content: If you think you shouldn't watch The Red Shoes because of the ballet you will be amazed. If you think it will be old-fashioned and boring you will be amazed.Ever since I saw this aged 5 it has been a family favourite. My three daughters love this and watch it over and over again, my brother and I sit together with our parents and watch this at Christmas . it is simply stunning, exhilarating, and above all full of the spirit of life.The struggle to create great art that consumes all involved is eternal, and the way the film is directed is faultless. Yes it is stylized but if you watch with open eyes and an open heart you are guaranteed an experience to last a lifetime.More than just a classic of the cinema it is a brilliant tale that genuinely makes the soul sing in a way that even Anchors Aweigh, and Fame, and Top Hat do not.Highest recommendation possible - one of THE films to see before you die.
The Red Shoes, one of Scorsese's favorite movies, is astounding piece of art and cinema. The dance scene is filmed beautifully and techincally impressive. Art.

reviews.review_title: One of the most factitiously gorgeous movies of all time, but there is a catch
reviews.content: If there is a poll of the most factitiously gorgeous movies of all time, Powell-Pressburger's THE RED SHOES will no doubt be surmounted on the top tier, for its kaleidoscopic use of Technicolor, highlighting the minutiae of its personages' fine complexion under sublime warpaint, carrying on to a fairyland luster that reflects the center story, and most extraordinarily, its scenography of phantasmagoria and spectacle, conjured up by art director Hein Heckroth. Certainly, for highbrow spectators, THE RED SHOES is an absolute humdinger even it is just for its eponymous ballet piece, written by Brian Easdale, choreographed by Robert Helpmann and headlined by a virtuoso Moira Shearer, this Hans Christian Andersen inspired magic tragedy has been roundly integrated into the narrative, where a budding prima ballerina Vicky Page (Shearer) is torn by her hankering to play her bespoke showpiece and the secular love with Julian Craster (Goring), a promising composer, and the blockade is set by the ballet impresario Boris Lermontov (Walbrook), who has discovered Vicky in the first place, and loathes whoever dares to blemish the purity of devotion to art by falling into that profane thing called love, already he has instantly dismissed another ballerina Irina (Tchérina) when she delightfully apprises the news that she is going to get married, so both Vicky and Julian should have known better.First of all, the ever-dapper Austrian actor Anton Walbrook effuses a superb air of condescension, complacency and cruelty that gives to the propulsion that the lax plot needs the most, calibrating every line and gesticulation with tacit investment of Boris' warped tunnel vision, he runs rings around his co-star Shearer and Goring as inhabiting "the man with no heart" with unyielding determination, he is at once obnoxious and fascinating. The fascination must be dialed down towards the ill-sorted pair, Ms. Shearer, is a fabulous dancer but not exactly what one might call as a supreme hyphenate, and even under the slap, furrows materializes on the face of Goring, who was 36 years old and looks like a doppelgänger of Dirk Bogarde (who would be a perfect Julian at a tender age of 27) to this reviewer's eyes, then yet has to play a sapling, so it is somewhat grating to see he is constantly referred as a "young man" by Irina (Tchérina is only 24), premature senility prevails, and that is not to say he is given much to do as the thankless fodder who bewitches Vicky into wedlock and cannot let her embrace the glory she yearns. Whereas viewers are showering in divine immersion of the most astonishing craftsmanship ever been executed on the screen, the discrepancy between its visual-and-aural extravaganza and a hoary, faintly incoherent (no effort is made to emphasize what the titular ballet means to Vicky, for instance) and evasive (unpunished plagiarism needs some scathing condemnation here) script only mars the ascension of THE RED SHOES as an irrefutable chef d'oeuvre that creates a harmonious symbiosis of cinema and ballet, and by the time they launch another attempt in THE TALES OF HOFFMANN (1951), the duo's mojo has drastically faded.

I love ballet and I love ballet films. I also love Hans Christian Andersen. This was beautifully acted, beautifully danced, and I cannot believe I have never seen it before. It perhaps moves a bit slowly in some parts, but otherwise I have no complaints.

reviews.review_title: The Red Shoes was, for nearly four decades, the most successful British film ever released in America.
reviews.content: A young ballerina (Moira Shearer) becomes a great star but comes under stress when torn between love and her career.Never was a better film made from such a plain story so unpersuasively written and performed; the splendour of the production is in the intimate view it gives of life backstage in the ballet world with its larger-than-life characters. The ballet excerpts are very fine, and the colour distinctive; the whole film is charged with excitement.Although loosely based on the Andersen story, it was also said to have been inspired by the real-life meeting of Sergei Diaghilev with the British ballerina Diana Gould. Diaghilev asked her to join his company, but he died before she could do so. Diana Gould later became the second wife of Yehudi Menuhin.

reviews.review_title: Nothing matters in the face of love
reviews.content: THE RED SHOES tells the tragic story of two people and their selfless love for each other and their respective passion in an egocentric world. A world which is phony, mendacious und destructive in it's very nature. A world in which authority is inextricably linked with seeming infallibility. A cold world in which talent, skills and people are just a commodity und not met with artistic respect.THE RED SHOES is equally a celebration and a swan song of art und the people running the art world. It's about the superficiality of the profound and about how it all doesn't matter in the face of love.

Obsessive ballet company director (Walbrook) sees the star potential in his young, naive protégée Vicky Page (real life ballerina Shearer in her film debut) after she performs the "Red Shoes" for his company, following the acrimonious departure of his former marquee ballerina (and prima-donna). Initially enthusiastic to be mentored by the great director, Page soon suffocates under his possessiveness, after he forbids her romance to the company composer, the pre-eminent Julian Craster (Goring). When Walbrook dismisses Goring after he fails to persuade him to end the romance, Shearer leaves the company in protest, but finds herself torn between two loves – that of the stage and the promise of greatness under Walbrook's watchful tutelage, and of her now husband Goring, himself on the verge of becoming a noted composer.This Powell-Pressburger collaboration of the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale is neither a fairy tale nor a ballet, in fact, it might draw parallels with the recent "Black Swan" in its contrasts of seemingly unbridled beauty and torrid sacrifice. Walbrook is a consummate performer, affecting a character whose capacity for praise and sympathy is concealed beneath a rigid, perfectionist exterior, bordering on megalomania. The scene in which his rage boils over and he strikes out at the mirror is impressive. Set design is, as perhaps you'd expect from the subject matter, exquisite in detail and the location work in Monte Carlo and Paris is divine.Without revealing the climax, I found it to be sudden and unexpected, reminiscent of a Hitchcock thriller in its method and impact. Probably not for all tastes, still I wouldn't suggest you'd need to be a connoisseur to appreciate the colour, romance, paranoia and suspense that is "The Red Shoes" which in spite of its vintage, remains a taut psychological drama/thriller.

This was the first film by directors Michael Powell & Emeric Pressburger that I saw, and personally I didn't really like it that much. Later I saw A Matter of Life and Death and was blown away by its brilliance, but for me, The Red Shoes just didn't make enough of a connection. The Red Shoes is a very emotionless film, a film that revolves more around style and film techniques than story, a very sad fact as the film could have been one of the best ever if it had, had just a little more to do with the character's lives and emotions. I just didn't buy the predicament that Victoria Page (Moira Shearer) and the writer Julian Craster (Marius Goring) found themselves in; their love just didn't transfer well enough for me to feel that bothered at the end. The performances (with the exception of Anton Walbrook) where underwritten and not all that well performed, but if the film has a saving grace, then it has to be the dance of the red shoes sequence, if only the film had had more ballet in it I might have been able to give this film a higher vote, but alas no. This is the only real dance number in the film. That said it's still one of the greatest scenes I've ever seen, with Jack Cardiff's amazing use of colour and angles. Not a great film, but it has enough beauty in twenty minutes that some films lack in a two-hour running time, for that the film gets 7/10.

A young ballet dancer is torn between the man she loves and her pursuit to become a prima ballerina.Although Michael Powell had a long career with many, many films under his belt, this is probably the one he is most associated with and remembered for. And, you have to admit, rightfully so. The color is great, as is the story and everything within.The layers are nice, as this is a movie about a ballet about a fairy tale. The scene (very brief) of the men picking out the perfect red shoes is gorgeous. And then my twisted mind wonders... what if this were a horror film? You know, a story where the shoes keep dancing even after the dancer stops?

This is a legendary movie but one that I only watched in it's entirety a couple of months ago. I always thought it would be a bit too high brow for my tastes as I knew it was set amongst the world of ballet. I was pleased to find that I enjoyed the movie a lot and it was one of those films that stuck in my mind.The central plot revolves around three character's and it is at times a complex relationship between the three. For what it's worth,this is my take on what exactly drove those people to act in the way they did.Boris Lermontov - A man with a true love of ballet. Driven,obsessive,selfish and above all a perfectionist. Always well groomed and immaculately turned out,he wants nothing but the very best for his ballet company. He grooms Victoria Page and sees in her the potential to be the best dancer in the world. Does he love her? I think that he loves the idea of making her the best dancer that she possibly can be. He does have feelings for her and that is something he has never felt for any dancer before. But love? No,just a selfish desire to own her,to feel that she can't function without him.Julian Craster - Similar to Boris in some ways. He too is driven and selfish but the major difference is that he is truly in love with Victoria. He is jealous of his wife's feelings for Boris as he states "You can dance anywhere but NOT here" when she is in turmoil after returning to Boris' ballet company. He too wants to own her and although his motives are selfish he is deeply in love.Victoria Page - A complex lady. In love with Julian and Boris but perhaps more in love with dance that anything else in her life. She leaves Boris for her love of Julian but it is dance that drives her to her death. Does she return because of Boris or the ballet? A bit of both and when faced with the decision to choose between her husband or dance,she chooses ballet,at least at first. Does she mean to kill herself? Her mind is in turmoil as she spurns her husband. She doesn't want to lose him,she doesn't want to lose her life's ambition to be the best dancer she possibly could be. It is here that the Red Shoes take over and as she runs to her husband she is blind to the peril that faces her. Ultimately she is stuck in the middle of a love triangle with her husband on one side and Boris on the other. The Red Shoes decide her fate.This is a film that deserves it's status as a classic. Gorgeous to look at and well acted. Moira Shearer exudes charm as Victoria, Marius Goring hits just the right note as Julian and there are nice touches from Robert Helpmann(Ivan) and Leonide Massine(Grischa). It has to be said though that the most compelling performance comes from Anton Walbrook as Boris. Confident,arrogant,charming and aloof,this is a fine performance that stays in the memory. Don't be put off by the theme of this movie. It is very well made and well worth watching.

This was the first film from the Powell-Pressburger team that I saw, and, to use a phrase that was popular at the time (early '80's), it knocked my socks off. Recently, it was among a handful of DVD's I loaned to a friend who was housebound for a week recovering from minor surgery. When she said "Oh, I've heard of this" with some trepidation, I responded, "It was sort of the MOULIN ROUGE of its day," knowing she was a fan of that movie. Though it really came off the top of my head, upon reflection I realized the comparison was apt.Though I can't say I was particularly impressed by MOULIN ROUGE, I have to give it credit for much of the same things I admire about THE RED SHOES." Both are innovative, and stretch the boundaries of film-making technology, narrative structure and visual design. They also have a thematic kinship, having to do with the conflict between love and career, which is symbolically expressed in a show-within-a-show.Here (with the possible exception of the effect on audiences of their respective periods), the similarities end. I bring them up only (as I did with my friend) as an incentive to those unfamiliar with THE RED SHOES (or Powell & Pressburger) who may not realize that work which seems so cutting-edge today is not all that new, and that there may be exciting viewing experiences in store for them from films made during an era to which they may not have given much consideration (or by which they may not have expected to be impressed).I'd also encourage any prospective viewers who might be put off by the "balletic" plot elements ("Ballet? Yuk!") to overcome such reservations. I can't imagine anyone who appreciates cinema craft at any level (and who isn't a complete Philistine) not uttering a quiet "Wow!" more than a few times during this picture.As with many Powell & Pressburger productions, THE RED SHOES is highly stylized at times and, despite comparisons made earlier here, a unique piece of film-making. All cinephiles owe themselves the opportunity to hop onto this magic carpet and be dazzled.

reviews.review_title: Will satisfy you to the core and leave you ravished
reviews.content:
Viewed at the 2000 Karlovy Vary film festival.
One of the great revelations of the week in Karlovy was the rediscovery, in a section devoted to older classics, of the great English ballet drama "The Red Shoes", from the year 1948. I had seen the film years before and remembered that it had impressed me way back then, but I had forgotten, or perhaps hadn't realized at the time, how truly magnificent and extraordinary this incredible picture actually is.
The basic plot is a love triangle between a beautiful red headed ballerina, her despotic impresario, and a younger musician, set in an incredibly colorful Monte Carlo. Moira Shearer, an actual professional ballerina was the dancer, and most imposing as the possessed impresario, was Austrian actor Anton Walbrook. This picture, based to a certain extent on a Danish fairy tale by Hans Christian Anderson in which a dancer dons red shoes which make her into a marvelous dancer, but then won't let go and force her to dance herself to death, is the perfect merger of classic dance, high Greek tragedy, and Hollywood staging. Unquestionably one of the most beautiful and compelling motion pictures ever made. 
 
"Red Shoes" directed by the British masters Powell and Pressburger, is the kind of picture that makes sitting through a thousand other banalities worth while, and makes you remember why you fell in love with the flickers in the first place. I was most delighted to find that the film would be repeated, and put everything else on hold so I could see it again the next night. Had there been nothing else of note during the festival, RED SHOES would have been enough to justify the trip. It's just one of those movies that satisfies you to the core and leaves you ravished. Words fail. See it if you ever get a chance, preferably on the big screen

reviews.review_title: A woman torn between personal and professional fulfillment
reviews.content: *POSSIBLE SPOILERS*"The Red Shoes" is the story of a woman who would like to live a life that is both professionally AND privately fulfilling - but the two men in her life (one personifying Love and Private Happiness, the other her professional passion, Dancing) do not permit her to incorporate both in her life. The conflict comes from the fact that neither man wants to recognize her as an artist and a personality in her own right, but rather as a vehicle of their own aspirations.During the budding romance with Craster, though, we see that her dream could be fulfilled: she dances to the music that he writes for her; both live a professionally and personally fulfilling life by cooperating. But Lermontov wants Vicky to be his creation and not to be attached to anyone or anything else except dancing. (It is obvious that he is not interested in her sexually or romantically - some said he might be gay, which can well be, but in the end, it doesn't matter, as Lermontov is rather the personification of his own ideal, a person only committed to his profession and to nothing and nobody else.)As the story develops, it turns out that to Craster, she is nothing more than an inspiration for his own work (he doesn't seem to bother that she is professionally unfulfilled while he reacts aggressively when she takes a step to dance again); to Lermontov, she is the clay she wants to form his own creation (a "great dancer") of. Though most supporting characters seem to recognize Vicky as an artist in her own right, the two men that matter most in her life do not. This is what leads ultimately to her downfall, as she is not able to choose between love and dancing, because both form a whole inside her. She rather sacrifices herself (though in the end it is not clear, to what extent) and thus affirms herself as a person and artist.A beautiful film (though not as supreme as I had expected it to be), with a great performance by Anton Walbrook and beautiful dancing scenes (though the not-so-perfect special effects in the otherwise highly original and captivating centerpiece were a bit disconcerting). I also like the passionate conflict of the story (the passion here is of the "sublimated" rather than of the downright erotic kind - it is very refreshing that the conflict between Vicky, Craster and Lermontov is not reduced to a mere love triangle). And, of course, a must for ballet lovers.

I wanted to see this film because of its reputation as one of Britain's finest films, but as I find with a lot of highly praised films your expectations are way too high and can't be fulfilled. I found "The Red Shoes" quite disappointing and not the amazing film I was led to believe it was. You have to admire the colour and style which is still incredible after 50 years. I also liked the music, and the ballet sequence was inventively directed, but Walbrook & Goring played characters who were not likeable which failed to draw you in to a story which was too melodramatic for you to care about. I've enjoyed all the Powell/Pressburger films that I have seen up to now and I think they are one of cinema's greatest treasures, but this one failed to excite me. (5/10)

It was sad to learn about Moira Shearer's death early this year. Even though she made very few films, (she retired around 1960 to dedicate herself to raising her family), her presence was always wonderful. There's not much I have to say that other users have not said, except that the romantic triangle between a dancer, an impresario and a pianist really works, and is the heart of the movie. (Not being a ballet fan myself, the ballet part was less appealing to me, though it wasn't bothersome either). The color is wonderful, and allows us to see the world in 1948 as if it were today. Perhaps the scene that stands most of my mind is the first one, with all the young people struggling to enter into the theater. This recalls an era where young people love classical music, and would treat its performers as if they were stars. That era would end just a few years later, when rock and roll come to the fore, and the world would never be the same. Whether this change was for the good or for the bad, let others decide. I know this, my late father was a teenager in 1948, and he left a lot of classical recordings of that era that he collected during that time, the same way young people collected rock records decades later.

reviews.review_title: Visually Stunning Portrait; The Eternal Triangle Translated Via Ballet
reviews.content: This is undeniably a film of extraordinary power by any genre's standards; it is also, I suggest, one of the most absorbing looks viewers have ever been granted on screen at the way in which artists--not hacks nor artists going about daily tasks but rather dedicated and even obsessed professional pursuers of the heightened-realism of beauty in the arts--risk themselves in pursuit of excellence. The high-energy level of the portrayal of ballet people is like the approach to a final dress rehearsal, not an ordinary day's work. The story-line concerns "The Red Shoes", a ballet suggested by a Hans Christan Anderson fairy tale about a young woman who dons lovely magic red foot-gear at the urging of her young man and of an evil wizard--supplying them to a shoemaker--and who then cannot remove them until she has danced herself to death. The same story-line is played out allegorically among three extraordinary talents--a brilliant young composer robbed of his work by a professor who is then commissioned to write "The Red Shoes" ballet music; his employer, an obsessive and dictatorial regisseur who runs his Lermontov Ballet Company with ruthless but perceptive perfectionist methods; and a lovely young, ambitious ballerina whom both love, who brings the ballet to the world's audiences. She goes off with the composer, deserting the ballet master after he has made possible her triumph in "The Red Shoes"; her fires the composer who succeeds on his ability. But half of what she wants in life is the perfection as an artist only he can drive her to. Faced with compelling and magnetic appeals and rewards offered by both those she admires and in her way loves, she kills herself, unable to choose between two courses that have unbalanced her mind. The film is another in the small but quite extraordinary series of works produced by Emmeric Pressburger and Michael Powell, which included "The Black Narcissus". The script was developed by Powell and Pressburger, with additional dialogue by Keith Winter and Marius Goring. The cinematography was done by the great Jack Cardiff, with production design by Hein Heckroth and art direction by Arthur Lawson. Brian Easdale and Kenny Baker are credited with the original music; Carven did the costumes. The "Red Shoes" ballet takes fifteen minutes, but most viewers seem to feel this centrally-placed art-work furthers the plot, as did the ballet in "Oklahoma" for instance. In the large cast, Ludmilla Tcherina is a quirky and moving grande dame of the dance, Robert Helpmann is powerful, Leonid Massine is as good as always, Moira Shearer is young and lovely as the young ballerina. But the film is dominated by Marius Goring's extraordinary young composer and Anton Wallbrook's award-level Boris Lermontov. The triangle these three bring to the screen is one of the most powerful ever realized on-screen, by my standards. The film is not as good in content as many believe because of its fatality aspects; but to overpraise its artistry--its presentation of visual beauty by suggestion and minimally-graphic assertion. This is a triumph for Jack Cardiff, for the audacious writer-producers and for British cinema in general, in my view. Comparing this film to ordinary story-lines is impossible; the theme of "seeking the highest, risking all for the highest in art" is not ordinary, but here is made central and necessary--and very memorable to an unforgettable achievement.

A young ballerina is torn between a struggling composer and an authoritarian impresario.The Red Shoes is often cited as one of the best films of all time, and I can see why. It's a beautifully made film. The cinematography is stunning, and the costumes and art direction are fantastic.Moira Shearer is quite good as the lead, and Anton Walbrook is fantastic. The supporting actors, such as Marius Goring, Albert Basserman, Esmond Knight and Robert Helpmann, are also good.Highly recommended. First time viewing. 5/5

When you watch the film documentaries of Martin Scorsese and read the reviews and commentaries of Roger Ebert, you might hear of names such as Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger and their films The Black Narcissus and The Red Shoes. And when you regard Scorsese and Ebert and their knowledge of film as highly as I do, you take note of their recommendations. Both men, particularly Scorsese who was involved in the restoration of the film, speak very highly of The Red Shoes. Based on this alone, I was interested in watching the film. I did, however, wonder if its subject matter of ballet would interest me. When I finally started the film with mom last night, I enjoyed it, but I must confess, at first I wondered what the high praise was for. Then, fifty-seven minutes into the film, came the first performance of The Red Shoes. It grabbed me and refused to relent. I was even entranced by the dancing. I then understood the acclaim. I shall attempt to convey the wonder of this film, but first a little background information.The Red Shoes came out in 1948. Its story concerns a dancer, Victoria Page, and a composer, Julian Caster. Both are hired by world renowned ballet producer, Boris Lermontov, with the promise that he will make them great. But this comes with a price: their undivided devotion to their art, to their dream, and to him. The film is about the pursuit of art and dreams and what happens when this is taken to its extreme, to the point of obsession.The title refers to a fairy tale, by Hans Christian Anderson, that Lermontov is adapting into a ballet. The fairy tale is described by Lermontov like this: "It is the story of a young girl who is devoured with an ambition to attend a dance in a pair of Red Shoes. She gets the shoes and goes to the dance. For a time, all goes well and she is very happy. At the end of the evening she is tired and wants to go home, but the Red Shoes are not tired. In fact, the Red Shoes are never tired. They dance her out into the street; they dance her over the mountains and valleys, through fields and forests, through night and day. Time rushes by, love rushes by, life rushes by, but the Red Shoes go on." Although I have never read Anderson's story, from this description alone, parallels can be seen throughout the film.Now, let's get back to fifty-seven minutes, the first performance of The Red Shoes. The film in general and this fifteen minute sequence specifically, is beautifully shot, seamlessly edited, and uses light and shadows to wondrous effect. Characters are transformed into other characters, a knife into tree branch. The red shoes are made to stand tip-toed on their own and the ballerina transported from standing by on stage to inhabiting them. A dancer morphs into a dancing newspaper and back again. Shadows grow larger and larger, taller and taller, threatening to attack the ballerina. But, alas, my words cannot do this film justice. Most viewers today, constantly inundated with CGI, would not be able to fully appreciate the brilliant artistry of all this. Again, this was 1948 when you actually had to be creative and achieve your effects in reality not with a computer. I found myself in awe of some of these shots, wondering how they were accomplished.The films color was also quite stunning for its time. Often the color in movies from this era look unnatural, but in The Red Shoes it is vibrant and full of life. I read that Technicolor considered this one of their best films. But I'm sure the quality of the picture is also due to the restoration process. As usual, Criterion did a marvelous job restoring and transferring the film to DVD. Although it was shot sixty-two years, it looks like it could have been made yesterday.Anymore, there seems to be a stigma on "old" movies. Do not let this or any preconceptions of the subject matter detract you from seeing The Red Shoes. It is a great film that will stay with you long after it has ended.Check out my other reviews at: notexactlyaquote.tumblr.com

"The Red Shoes" lets us see the fabulous technique of Moira Shearer's (Victoria page) classical dancing, and also the dated and slow-motion technique of Ludmilla Tcherina (Irina). Except for Leonide Massine, all of the male dancers in principal roles were pathetic. These are the "stars" who were left-over from "Ballet Russe" ? Male dancers in The USA were much better, even in those early days. "Trivia" tells us that even J. Arthur Rank (whose name the movie was released under) walked-out of the movie, thinking it was a dud. The whole production was almost shelved, with only a print released to a theater in New York City, where it played for 110 weeks. Universal Studios realized it was a masterpiece and released it nationwide.Many of the reviews posted here talk about the brilliance of the colors in the film. Doesn't anyone remember that "Gone with the Wind" was released IN COLOR at the beginning of the '40s? By the time "Shoes" was released, Hollywood had made many wonderful films in color by 1948 !! I guess younger "users" think that was in The Dark Ages. The cinematography certainly helped "The Red Shoes" become the hit it was and is.Moira Shearer's fabulous technique was apparent even in the rehearsal scenes for the new ballet - here was a major talent, over-shadowed by Margot Fonteyn. Both of them appeared in The Sadler Wells company, as soloists, at the same time. Scandals and gossip about that lady's romance with a certain Russian dancer helped to keep Ms. Shearer's superior technique in the background. However, she was a major dancer for years, but actually was not too anxious to dance in "The Red Shoes" - in which the fame for her dancing could not escape her and surely set an example for other ballerinas.This movie showed the backstage politics of ballet companies. Powell's script only had to be minimal, just to let the viewers see how a company worked, with small sub-plots to depict how a temperamental assembly of performers interacted. Pressberger's skill to get it all together was essential, a job well-done. The real star of the movie was Brian Easdale's score for "The Red Shoes Ballet" and Ms. Shearer's dancing.It's difficult to realize that Russian audiences could attend the theater for pennies for decades, while the art had barely caught-on in this country. Now, major ballet-companies are struggling to stay onstage, even the Russians having financial problems. I clearly remember rehearsal-halls being built in a famously old theater in Los Angeles for a major company, who got cold feet after the riots in the early 1990s. I understand Los Angeles ain't "The Big Apple", but that theater has turned into a major venue for rock-stars and bands, because it's big enough to make money, but small enough for them to play a more intimate venue to get close to their fans. The seats on the bottom floor were removed and a dance-floor put in, and it's rocking........it also can be set with tables and chairs for more romantic acts. The Wiltern is always busy.The actual "Red Shoes Ballet" in the movie is a miraculous piece of work. Nothing was spared to present its fairytale to let every viewer escape into its magic, getting actually involved from all sides, not just looking at it from the front. Anton Walbrook (Lermontov) was brilliant in his role - the perfect dictator of a talent-driven company. His acting was totally believable. All the supporting actors-actresses were superb, with the plot being about ballet - period. I wasn't impressed with Marius Goring's (Craster) role, because he wasn't nearly handsome enough for the gorgeous Ms. Shearer - he needed to be dashing and full of fire. That her character gave-up her career to be the wilting wife was a stretch for me, because her whole life was about dancing.The tireless red shoes that refused to stop dancing drove the plot of the entire movie - and provided a tragic, fairytale ending. One viewing of this masterpiece is not enough - although the movie is older that most of the people seeing it today - except me - it is ageless. Give yourself a treat that you'll never regret - buy this DVD or VHS to watch when you need inspiration. I'm sure you'll rate it a 15, just as I did.....1/23/08 - just lucked-up on TCM/s presentation of this brilliant film last night. The print was fabulous, apparently transferred to DVD - so thankful to see it was done in it's original, full-screen version: wide-screen would have cut all the heads off. If you haven't seen it yet, search for it - it's still a thriller.

reviews.review_title: What a delight this movie is
reviews.content: In an era where nothing is sacred and corporate profits supercede personal worth, watching a movie as beautifully created and finely acted as this helps us remember how much beauty there really is around us.Hans Christian Andersen's "The Red Shoes" - a moral tale about a mischievous shoemaker who tempts a young girl or boy into buying the beautiful shoes, only to discover that they cause him/her to dance restlessly until he/she dies - is the metaphor central to this movie and plays itself out both in the movie's ballet masterpiece and the lives of the characters.The ballet company producer is a tortured and possessive man who wants to own the prima donna of the story in the same way that incomplete people want to own and absorb the beauty of something or someone else. But an off-stage romance between the leading lady and the genial composer leads to a rivalry of ownership and a seminal final scene where the Moira Shearer character is forced to choose between her husband or her dancing career.I gather this was a highly political movie of its time. Made in the years shortly after the war, it was probably an attempt by the British film-makers to make sense of the war's madness; this probably accounts for the looming Lermontov's possessiveness and ultimate destructiveness.However, not only the movie's plot line and beautiful direction appeals. Also, the moments when the movie depicts 1948 street life have an amazing effect on you. Seeing steam-trains and pleated summer dresses and reflections of a more innocent age all contribute to the movie's beauty and appeal.

The Red Shoes is based on a fairy tale, about a girl who puts on the red shoes, that then dance her to death. This wonderful movie uses the tale as the beginning of a tragedy for a young ballerina who has to choose between her love of dancing, and the love of her boyfriend.The acting by the entire cast is brilliant. I watched this on DVD, and it revealed that the majority of the cast were actual ballet dancers that had to act, not the other way round as would be normal. The result of this is that the acting side does have the occasional flaw (as for most it would be their first acting experience), but it makes all the dancing and behind the scenes action almost real.As I said most of the actors were real dancers, but special credit has to go to Moira Shearer. Already established as a ballerina, she does very well in her performance of the girl torn in two. The acting star of the movie though is Anton Walbrook. His performance as Lermontov, the owner of the ballet company is sensational. At times brutal, others almost compassionate, his performance dominates the movie. Watch his last speech in the movie for proof of this.The real stars of this movie are Micheal Powell & Emeric Pressburger. They'd already made several classics, such as A Matter Of Life And Death (a personal fav. of mine), and Black Narcissus. This easily sits alongside those movies. Also deserving special mention is Jack Cardiff's stunning photography, and the production design by Hein Heckroth. More of an artist, his sets and imagination shine through, especially with the stunning 17 minute ballet sequence in the middle of the movie. This scene, the ballet version of the red shoes story, easily sits up there as one of the best dance sequences ever put to film...and I never thought I'd say that as I'm not a ballet fan, but the scene is extraordinary. This sequence at times shows more imagination and originality than some newer movies do. And the effects used, though dated by todays standards still hold up well.I'm not sure I'd go so far as to call it a musical, more a romantic drama set in a ballet company, but whatever you wish to class it as, it deserves to be seen.

reviews.review_title: The most successful British film ever made!
reviews.content: NOTES: From a worldwide attendance standpoint, the most successful British film ever made! With an initial rentals gross of over $5 million, number 1 at the U.S./Canadian box-office for 1948, easily beating off challenges from Road to Rio, The Paleface, Easter Parade and Red River, each of whom grossed $4.5 million. Oddly, this superb result was not duplicated in the U.K. itself. The film did manage to claim the number 10 position, but it was beaten by British picture- goers' far greater preferences for (in order) Spring in Park Lane, The Best Years of Our Lives, My Brother Jonathan, The Road to Rio, Life with Father, It Always Rains on Sunday, Naked City, Oliver Twist, and Unconquered. Second to The Paleface at Australian ticket windows for 1949. Number 1 English-language movie at the French box-office. Number two in the 1949 Film Daily poll of American film critics. A New York Times "Ten Best" for 1948. Film debut of Moira Shearer.COMMENT: A marvelously entertaining movie which succeeds brilliantly — against the odds. The idea of planning the ballet in advance (see Jean Osborne's review below) sounds crackpot to me, but it works. And it just doesn't come off reasonably well, but with power and certitude. Also none too promising were such old hat plot stratagems as a Diaghilev impresario thwarting young love (cf. Waterloo Bridge) and a composer whose music is stolen (cf. the Claude Rains Phantom of the Opera). But thanks partly to absolutely riveting performances; partly to a script crowded with realistically drawn characters, given some wonderfully caustic dialogue, and jam-packed with fascinating incidental touches; partly to masterful direction; partly to evocative music and appealing dancing; partly to superb color in sets and costumes, beguiling outdoor locations and breathtaking production values, The Red Shoes is a masterpiece of absolutely engrossing entertainment. Hard to believe it runs 133 minutes. Seems more like 33.Needless to say the mysticism and religiosity of Andersen's tale has been completely expunged from the main story, though these elements are still reflected in the ballet.

At the first of the movie my mind was busy with my life, my day, my future decisions, my wrong choices. it was so loud I couldn't keep up with the movie only glimpses here and there and suddenly the part where the the red shoes opera start. Everything comes to silents .all I can feel now is beauty filling the bores of my soul, I was shocked and stunned keeping track with those red shoes, how marvelous that scene was it fill my heart with joy for few minutes I was in a dream world lost my self with such art , it drop a tear from my eye how it was impossible to escape my head. I appreciate this movie for Succesing in disconnecting me away from this heavy life.

reviews.review_title: Who keeps messing up the transliterations?
reviews.content: Well, Michael Powell's Academy Award-nominated production here was one of the most over-the-top movies that I've ever seen. I appreciate the effort that they put into "The Red Shoes", but the movie's exaggerated sense of itself led me to throw out MST3K-style comments while watching it (i.e., implying that the shoes were possessed a la "The Exorcist" or "Poltergeist"). The whole dance sequence looked like the result of an acid trip.Amid all this, one thing about the movie really bothered me: the transliterations of people's names. We see spellings like Grischa Ljubov and Ivan Boleslawsky. It appears that someone tried to mix English transliterations of Russian names with German transliterations. Proper English ones would be Grisha Lyubov and Ivan Boleslavsky, while proper German ones would be Grischa Ljubow and Iwan Boleslawski. It proliferates even further once you get to French and Italian transliterations (don't even get me started on Czech and Polish).OK, that was tangential. My point is that while one can admire the dancers' passion with their work, you're likely to find the movie's pompous, heavy-handed seriousness a little corny, and some of the sequences will leave you thinking "I want some of what they're smoking!" Still, Moira Shearer is definitely a real babe in this movie.

The question isn't whether The Red Shoes is the best movie of all time-- it belongs in the discussion-- but whether it's the greatest work of art, period.Its famed centerpiece, The Red Shoes ballet, alone qualifies it for such consideration. Never has there been such full display of visual and aural art-- the music, sets, and costumes are a culmination of modernist art up to that point in time (1948). Surreal and expressionist, with touches of jazz and Dada. This, accompanied by inspired dancing from world-class ballerina Moira Shearer and others, and shot in phenomenal three-strip Technicolor.The experience is like walking through the most vibrant art museum imaginable.The film is more than the set-piece ballet, of course. It's the ultimate depiction of the creation of art. As a character says, of "something from nothing." A must-see for anyone who aspires to create-- for the ideals expressed in the film as well as the created film: the structure holding the ideals and ideas in place. Plot threads overlap then come together. Notice how the featured ballet is set up, backstage flurries, worries, and nerves, and expectant audience, the building of suspense, so we the viewers of the movie are as filled with anticipation and tension as the dancers themselves.(Films used to regularly set up their most thrilling sequences, instead of throwing them at the audience non-stop. The 1959 version of Ben-Hur for instance, does this with its justly famous chariot race.)One could write volumes about everything going on psychologically in The Red Shoes. One of them is impresario Boris Lermontov as all-controlling artistic god. This shown from the beginning when he's unseen behind a curtain while his ballet company frolics on stage-- seeming from a distance like puppets. Like a wrathful god, Lermontov also displays anger when two of his puppets later disobey him.Or: the male gaze, when Lermontov in the audience views fledgling star Victoria Page dancing with a local theater company-- and she realizes he's there.The restored-version DVD from the Criterion Collection is the next best thing to seeing The Red Shoes on film in a movie theater.A perfect work of art? Maybe, despite the melodramatic-but-inevitable ending. All elements of cinema work together flawlessly-- acting (special nods to Anton Walbrook and Ms. Shearer), the Brian Easdale score, cinematography, script, direction: everything.

Art films are rarely successful interpretations relying more on arts for arts sake than to carry through a complete story through development to conclusion. The Red Shoes is an ballet art film and it is a successful dramatic film which excels in telling the story of a lovely young dancer who must decide between her desire to dance or to live as the wife of a composer. Moria Scherer is the lovely ballet dancer who is placed in the cross hairs of a powerful impresario, Boris Lermontov (Anton Walbrook) who is both mentor and obsessive that his principal dancer remain faithful only to the company and his direction. As she tries to make her way in the company, she is plucked from the chorus by Lermontov to dance the principal lead in the new ballet, "The Red Shoes." To familiarize her with the music, Lermontov asks his assistant conductor, Julian Krasner (Marius Goring) to play for her during her off-stage as well as on-stage moments. Throwing the two young rising stars together, Lermontov accidentally set the scene for their falling in love, a situation that is intolerable for the jealous, controlling director.A cinematic high point of the film is the 20 minute ballet of the Red Shoes, which for students and lovers of the ballet is one of the great treats of dance film history. Incorporating the stylized ballet of the 40s, it is a window into the formal method of partnering and choreography which was the European style of ballet and staging familiar to European audiences, but rarely seen in the U.S. Incorporating a surrealistic look, the ballet foreshadows the dilemma which the young Vickie is soon to experience herself with disastrous results. Other snips from the classical repertoire featured in the film include Copellia, rarely danced today, Ballet Fantastique, Les Sylphide, and Swan Lake. One dancer who appears in the film from the noteworthy companies of the period is the brilliant choreographer and dancer, Leonide Massine, who as Grecia Lubov, recreates several of the leading roles from his own stellar career in Russia and Europe.This is a film made for color with shocking use of vibrant reds and blues which literally stun the eye. Shot on location in Monte Carlo and London, the film reflects the plush settings of the great resort lifestyle with its opulence and grandeur. If films of art, music, and fantasy are your cup of tea, The Red Shoes is the film to watch. It is a visual exultation of music and ballet through the work of a great production team of Pressburger and Powell, and is a film never to be forgotten.

A mesmerising film by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger. The film is about a young ambitious female dancer Vicki, who joins a ballet company directed by an authoritarian impresario, Lermontov. Vicki's first performances of 'The Red Shoes' have brought her fame and fortune, and her romantic relationship with a younger composer Julain Craster develops; however, Lermontov's discovery of Vicki's romance with Julian leads to his rage, and results in both Vicki and Julian leaving the company. Lermontov's curt demeanour, and demands for obedience puzzle Vicki. Vicki's quandary in choosing between her romance and life as a prima ballerina leads to tragedy.The compelling cinematography, riveting and atmospheric music, the thrilling dichotomy in Vicki's are the elements in which mark this film as one of the classics of all time. Three art forms, dance, music and film are intertwined skilfully in The Red Shoes. Powell Pressburger team provides the audience enigmatic experience throughout the film with the use of mystifying lighting, compositions, and character development. The scene where Lermontov in his sombre room breaks the mirror with his fists, symbolizes and signposts the upcoming tragedy which is looming towards the end of this film. 17 minutes sequence of the ballet scene makes this film grand-breaking and exemplary to other films in the decades to come. Surreal elements in the scenes of The Red Shoes create parallels with Vicki's life as a lover and ballet dancer.

reviews.review_title: A brilliantly conceived ballet as a haunting metaphor
reviews.content:
I'm someone who knows close to zero about ballet. I was drawn to this film by its reputation. I will leave a detailed analysis of the film to other viewers who know its history. I'll just say that the staging of the actual ballet of  The Red Shoes' is brilliant. Powell and Pressberger have managed to take you into the subjective world of the dancers while keeping them on the stage. It is perhaps the finest cinematic representation of art's magical ability to transport the artist into another world. One note on the Criterion DVD transfer: while the color saturation is good, there seems to have been a problem with the timing. You can watch an actor's flesh tones change several times in the course of a few seconds (which is a little distracting). Given the great quality of Criterion's other transfers, I can only assume that this is a problem with the source material. The audio quality also suffers by comparison to modern standards.
But my complaints about the transfer do not diminish the accomplishments of Powell and Pressberger in turning the story of The Red Shoes' into a great ballet and a haunting metaphor about art, artists and sacrifice.

A young ballerina must choose between dance and romance. As with other films by Powell and Pressburger, this one is enhanced by vibrant color cinematography. The ballet scenes are fabulous, featuring graceful dancing and wonderful music. Unfortunately, the ballet scenes comprise only a small part of the film, with the rest devoted to mundane events in the lives of the ballerina (Shearer), her lover (Goring, who looks like Dirk Bogarde), and the coach (Walbrook). Shearer is a terrific dancer but she's no actress. Walbrook's emotionless, monotonous acting style was better suited to his character in "The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp." The film seems to go on forever and has a silly finale.

Coming from the Powell-Pressburger team you shouldn't be surprised. This is not only one of the best dance films ever, is THE film about artists. It tells the story of a unknown ballerina (Moira) who becomes who is between the love of two possessive men: A composer and famous ballet producer. Art imitates life.The movie could take the Anderson beautiful tale in form as Powell do with THE TALES OF Hoffman or maybe what Bergman do with THE MAGIC FLUTE, but Powell-Pressburger uses the tale as a metaphor of the future confrontation of our leading lady between her life, her job or her love. And the ending is a heart breaker. And are the Technicolor sets and, what it could be the typical MGM musical long dance sequence is masterful, beautiful scene that keep your senses out of orbit.A MUST. A CLASSIC. Though Criterion Collection can be observed as an easy choice with their fame, their print is definitely not the best (Actually is kind of poor) ... There's an European edition that, it seems, contains the best negative.

reviews.review_title: Incredible dancing goes on and on!
reviews.content: Film based around the classic Hans Christian Anderson tale of the 'Red Shoes', starring Moira Shearer.  I'd wanted to see this for quite a while and even though it didn't quite live up to my expectations, I couldn't fault any of the amazing ballet sequences, which make it easy to see why this film has become such a classic.  A good turn too by Shearer, who shows real emotion as the girl torn between her love of the ballet and her love for the young composer (Marius Goring)

Over the last month,I have unexpectedly been drawn to watching films that have ballet dancing as a main theme to the plot.Soon after I had ordered Suspiria and Black Swan,I began to hear about a film which is meant to be the main inspiration for all future ballet films.Searching round for information about the film,I was thrilled to find out that it had been made by Michael Powell and Emeric Preesburger,whose stunning work I had just recently in the sadly forgotten film Gone To Earth. With having read the huge amount of praise that this particular film of theirs has received,and also having been hugely entertained by Gone To Earth,I started to get myself ready, for something very special which I was about to see..The plot:For Victoria Page dancing has been something thats been in her veins since the very beginning of her life.With having spent most of her young adult life taking part in small,independent ballet productions.Thinking that she is never going to reach the top in her career,Victoria is left speechless when her aunt,tells her that she has sorted out an opportunity for Page to meet one of the worlds most successful ballet producer's:Boris Lermontov.At the after-show celebration of Lermontovs latest production,Victorias aunt goes up to Boris to ask him if her niece Victoria could do an audition for him.Being left almost speechless,due to a "nobody" thinking that they are worthy to even attempt to get a role in his production,Lermontov instantly leaves the party.Despite Borises signs of obvious anger towards them,Victoria keeps trying to get him to watch an audition of her's.Realising that Lermontov is never going to give her opportunity she so desires,Page instead decides that she will stick to doing local ballet performance,although Victoria is completely unaware that Boris has accepted an invitation to go and watch the "small" ballet show,which she has a lead part in.. With at last having (actidentally) seen Victoria perform,Lermontov rushes up to tell her that her ballet perform is "the most pure and beautiful" that he has ever seen.Having now become very impressed with her performance,Boris finally gives Victoria Page the offer her whole life has been building up to:being in a Lermontov production.Shortly after Victoria signs the contract,Boris gives her the opportunity of having the lead role in his next production,due to his main dancer having been fried for getting married.After accepting the offer,Boris tells her that there is one rule that he has,which she and everyone else has to follow,which is to never fall in love,due to Lermontov feeling that it completely ruins the performance of the show.Shortly after having signed Victoria,a young wannabe composer called Julian Craster runs into Lermontovs office,demanding that he be given the chance to play some of the music he has recently been writing.Feeling intrigued by the brash confidence that Craster has shown him,Boris accepts Jullians offer.Due to having caught a glimpse of Craters talent,Lermontov decides to hire Julian as his main composer,and instantly gives him the huge challenge of writing the next production.To his amazement,Julian writes the next production (The Red Shoes) in record time.On the opening night,Lermontov is thrilled when everyone tells him that this is one of the best ballets that they have ever seen.At the after show party,he looks round for Victoria and Craster without any luck at all.Suddenly,someone that has worked backstage on The Red Shoes tells Boris that the reason he can not find either of them,is because they have both gone to take a ride in a horse and carriage,due to having fallen deeply in love for each other... View on the film:The first thing which I feel this truly beautiful film should be praised for,is the astonishing,twenty minute long performance of The Red Shoes ballet.For this twenty minute sequence Producers/screenwriters (along with Keith Winter) and co-directors Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger create,what is possibly the nearest I have ever seen a film come to showing an actually dream!.The sequence cleverly mixes the theatre setting of the film,with the stunning filming technique of Powell and Pressburger,who with some well timed sudden jump-cuts,120 brilliant paintings by the under rated Hein Heckroth and some very tough looking wire work for the dancers,that help to give a strange gravity-defying feel to the sequence.Whilst most film makers would perhaps just let one sequence in their film be the main thing that blows everyone away,here Powell and Pressburger show that there is no chance at all,that they will let any moment of the film just be "ok".For the great screenplay,which they co-wrote with Keith Winter,Powell and Pressburger very elegantly balance the script,so that there are quite a few funny moments early on in the film with Boris Lermontov (terrificly played by Anton Walbrook),whilst they make sure that Victoria Pages never ending desire to dance is the main foundation for the films plot,with her first attempts to get a role in Lermontovs productions being shown in a slight comedic light,and then gradually changed,into showing her addiction to ballet dancing consuming entire soul.After having immensely enjoyed Moira Shearers performance of Victoria Page,I went searching online to try and find out some more information about her,Which eventually led to me discovering the complete surprise that Shearer was not keen on the film at all,and although I can understand the reasons why Moria disliked making the film so much.(mainly due to the intense amount of dancing and wire work which she had to do) I strongly feel that her performance is truly mesmerising,with the scenes where Victoria feels the pain of her addiction to ballet,that has caused her to lose everything else around her being painful to watch,thanks to Morias very intense performance. Final view on the film:One of the greatest,most beautifully perfect films that I have ever seen.
